**Case Summary: V-Guard Industries Ltd. vs. Rakesh Malhotra & Ors. and V-Guard Industries Ltd. vs. Vave India Energy Solutions Private Limited & Ors.**

**Background:**
The case involves a trademark dispute between V-Guard Industries Ltd. (the plaintiff) and Rakesh Malhotra & Ors. (the defendants) regarding the use of the trademark "LIVGUARD" which the plaintiff claims is deceptively similar to its own trademark "V-GUARD". The plaintiff had previously filed a suit (OS no. 12/2013) before the District Court, Ernakulam, seeking permanent injunction against the defendant's use of the "LIVGUARD" trademark. The suit was dismissed, and the plaintiff's appeal before the Kerala High Court was also dismissed.

**Legal Issues:**
The plaintiff filed two new suits, CS(COMM) 1018/2016 and CS(COMM) 814/2018, before the High Court of Delhi, seeking permanent injunction against the defendants for passing off their goods using the "LIVGUARD" trademark and for using a similar trade dress. The defendants filed applications under Section 10 of the Code of Civil Procedure (CPC) seeking a stay of the suits until the disposal of an appeal (RFA 117/2017) filed by the plaintiff before the Kerala High Court against the judgment and decree dated 22nd November 2016.

**Arguments:**
The plaintiff's senior counsel stated that no reply was required to be filed to the defendants' applications. The plaintiff claimed that the "LIVGUARD" trademark is deceptively similar to its own "V-GUARD" trademark and that the defendants' use of the mark would cause confusion among consumers. The defendants argued that their trademark "LIVGUARD" is not similar to the plaintiff's "V-GUARD" trademark and that the plaintiff's suits were an attempt to harass them.

**Court Findings:**
The High Court of Delhi, after considering the history of the litigation and the previous judgments, found that the plaintiff's suits were an attempt to re-agitate issues that had already been decided by the Kerala High Court. The court noted that the plaintiff had previously filed a suit before the District Court, Ernakulam, which was dismissed, and that the plaintiff's appeal before the Kerala High Court was also dismissed.

**Decision:**
The High Court of Delhi allowed the defendants' applications under Section 10 of the CPC and stayed the suits (CS(COMM) 1018/2016 and CS(COMM) 814/2018) until the disposal of the appeal (RFA 117/2017) filed by the plaintiff before the Kerala High Court. The court held that the plaintiff's suits were an attempt to re-litigate issues that had already been decided by the Kerala High Court and that the defendants' use of the "LIVGUARD" trademark was not deceptively similar to the plaintiff's "V-GUARD" trademark.

**Conclusion:**
In conclusion, the High Court of Delhi stayed the plaintiff's suits, allowing the defendants to continue using the "LIVGUARD" trademark until the disposal of the appeal before the Kerala High Court. The court's decision highlights the importance of respecting previous judgments and the need for parties to refrain from re-agitating issues that have already been decided by courts of competent jurisdiction.

According to the PDF document "VGUARD INDUSTRIES LTD VS. RAKESH MALHOTRA & ORS.pdf", the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi delivered a judgment on January 9, 2023, in the case CS(COMM) 1018/2016 and CS(COMM) 814/2018. The plaintiff, V-Guard Industries Ltd, was represented by Mr. Akhil Sibal, Senior Advocate, and others. The court decided on two applications, allowing both and staying the present suits with liberty to revive them after a decision in RFA 117/2017 pending before the Kerala High Court.

The case involves a claim of passing off, which was initially filed before the District Court, Ernakulam. The plaintiff's interim application was dismissed, and the appeal against the order was also dismissed by the Kerala High Court. The plaintiff then filed an application to withdraw part of the claim, which was allowed by the District Judge, Ernakulam, permitting the plaintiff to file a fresh suit. The plaintiff subsequently filed CS(COMM) 1018/2016.

The court rejected the plaintiff's submission that the bar under Section 10 of the CPC only applies to the trial of the suit, giving the term "trial" a narrow meaning. The court held that the term "trial" includes the entire process of recording evidence and addressing final arguments. The judgment was delivered by Amit Bansal, J., on January 9, 2023, as stated in the PDF document (2023/DHC/000134). The date of January 23, 2023, was cancelled, and the cases were stayed pending further decisions.
